details.title: Reliability Modeling: Linear Combination and Ratio of Exponential and Rayleigh

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Florida Int. Univ., Miami, FL

p: B. M. Golam Kibria is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Statistics at the Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, USA. His research interests include distribution theory, estimation theory, predictive inference, ridge regression, reliability, and applied statistics. He has over 40 papers published or accepted in international statistical journals. He has held positions at Jahangirnagar University, Bangladesh, University of Western Ontario, and the University of British Columbia, Canada. He is the Elected Fellow of the International Statistical Institute, and an Elected Fellow of the Royal Statistical Society. He is the member of the editorial board of the Pakistan Journal of Statistics, International Journal of Statistical Science, and Pakistan Journal of Statistics and Operation Research; and he is the Associate Editor of THE Journal of Probability and Statistical Science.

authors.name: B. M. Golam Kibria

p: Saralees Nadarajah is a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics, University of Manchester, Manchester, M13 9PL, UK. His research interests include climate modeling, extreme value theory, distribution theory, information theory, sampling and experimental designs, and reliability. He is an author/co-author of four books, and has over 300 papers published or accepted. He has held positions in Florida, California, and Nebraska.

details.abstract: The distributions of linear combinations, and ratios of random variables arise explicitly in many reliability problems. This has increased the need to have available the widest possible range of statistical results on products of random variables. In this paper, the exact distributions of alphaX+betaY, and X/Y are derived when X, and Y follow two of the most applied models in reliability. Computer programs for calculating the associated percentage points are also given

references.title:
The mean time-to-failure of some special series-parallel
arrays

context.text: In many systems which are composed of components, the system failure time can be expressed as a sum or a linear combination of component life times [1], [2].

links.abstract: A method for finding the mean time-to-failure (MTTF) of parallel-series and series-parallel arrays is presented. The system itself is subject to two modes of failure, open and short, and all components states are mutually independent. Each item has the same failure-time distribution, and the probability of short failure of an item, given the failure of the item, is a constant. It is shown that the distribution of the lifetime of the system is a linear combination of the distributions of lifetime...

references.text: S. Iyer, "The mean time-to-failure of some special series-parallel arrays", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 40, pp. 20-21, 1991.

references.title:
Closed-form expressions for distribution
of sum of exponential random variables

context.text: In many systems which are composed of components, the system failure time can be expressed as a sum or a linear combination of component life times [1], [2].

links.abstract: In many systems which are composed of components with exponentially distributed lifetimes, the system failure time can be expressed as a sum of exponentially distributed random variables. A previous paper mentions that there seems to be no convenient closed-form expression for all cases of this problem. This is because in one case the expression involves high-order derivatives of products of multiple functions. The authors prove a simple intuitive multi-function generalization of the Leibnitz ru...

references.text: S. V. Amari, R. B. Misra, "Closed-form expressions for distribution of sum of exponential random variables", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 46, pp. 519-522, 1997.

component lives

links.abstract: The exact distribution of the sum of 2 independent beta variables is presented. It is applied to a standby system with beta-distributed component lives and permits the calculation of its exact reliability when the exact parameters-values are known. It appreciably improves the current approximate method.

references.text: T. G. Pham, N. Turkkan, "Reliability of a standby system with beta-distributed component lives", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 43, pp. 71-75, 1994.
